reasoning: The critique targets section 2.4’s realism/antirealism-based argument for pessimism about WAM-convergence, which is an important support for the paper’s broader skepticism about widespread convergence, but not the only support (the essay also appeals to sociological/incentive/technology/"blocker" considerations). So centrality is moderate. The critique’s main point—that the authors don’t defend an exhaustive meta-ethical partition and ignore constructivism/error theory/hybrids—is partly right, but its impact is limited because the authors explicitly offer a label-free restatement in terms of convergence behavior across starting points, which many “third options” would still need to answer, and because the overall case doesn’t stand or fall on this dilemma alone. The critique is clear, focused, and has little fluff, but it overstates when it says the argument’s force “depends entirely” on the binary being comprehensive.
title: The realism-antirealism dilemma ignores constructivist and hybrid meta-ethical positions
